revision.text:
'''Sexism in medicine''' involves discriminating against patients, physicians, medical students and medical-school staff on the basis of gender. Most sexism is directed against women.<ref name = zhuge/><ref>That sexism usually refers to discrimation against women, see, for example, {{cite encyclopedia |last1=Cudd|first1=Ann E.|last2=Jones|first2=Leslie E.|editor1-last=Frey|editor1-first=R. G.|editor2-last=Wellman|editor2-first=Christopher Heath | name-list-format = vanc | title=Sexism |encyclopedia=A Companion to Applied Ethics |year=2008|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qws8gf4f4iUC&pg=PA102|publisher=Blackwell |location=London|pages=102–105}}</ref> The discrimination can involve comments on women's appearance; the imposition of an aggressive "macho" culture; verbal abuse; bullying; sexual assault; being passed over for promotion; and being denied treatment.<ref name=Grant-Kels2017>{{cite journal | vauthors = Grant-Kels JM | title = Sexism in medicine, circa 2016-2017 | journal = International Journal of Women's Dermatology | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 68–69 | date = March 2017 | pmid = 28492058 | pmc = 5418952 | doi = 10.1016/j.ijwd.2017.01.007 }}</ref><ref name=Herbst2016>{{cite news|last1=Herbst|first1=Allyson|title=This is the kind of sexism women who want to be doctors deal with in med school|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2016/10/04/this-is-the-kind-of-sexism-women-who-want-to-be-doctors-deal-with-in-med-school|work=The Washington Post|date=4 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wiggins C | title = Barriers to women's career attainment | journal = Journal of Health and Human Services Administration | volume = 17 | issue = 3 | pages = 368–78 | date = 4 September 1995 | pmid = 10153076 }}</ref> Assessing the differences in pain treatment and the report of pain between men and women is complicated by the possibility that men and women perceive or experience pain differently.<ref name = girl>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hoffmann DE, Tarzian AJ | title = The girl who cried pain: a bias against women in the treatment of pain | journal = The Journal of Law, Medicine & Ethics | volume = 29 | issue = 1 | pages = 13–27 | date = 2001 | pmid = 11521267 | doi = 10.1111/j.1748-720X.2001.tb00037.x }}</ref> Men in nursing are often subjected to sexist treatment.
==Female patients== Female patients are often treated differently from men. Women have been described in studies and in narratives as emotional and [[Hysteria|hysterical]].<ref name="huff2017">{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/nimisha-aithal/sexism-in-medicine-needs-a-checkup_a_22017856/|title=Sexism In Medicine Needs A Checkup|last=Aithal|first=Nimisha | name-list-format = vanc |date=2017-04-02|work=Huffington Post|language=en-AU}}</ref> Historically, [[women's health]] has been called "bikini medicine". In addition, some physicians assume that women should be assessed and receive identical treatments as men. Narratives include the reporting that women's complaints are considered exaggerated and may be assumed to be invalid.<ref name=marieclaire/><ref name=Atlantic>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/10/emergency-room-wait-times-sexism/410515/|title=How Doctors Take Women's Pain Less Seriously|first=Joe|last=Fassler| name-list-format = vanc |publisher=Atlantic|date=15 October 2015}}</ref> Because of this women are often subsequently are referred to [[psychiatrist]]s for treatment.<ref name = marieclaire/> The tendency of treating pain in women with antidepressants exposes the women to developing side effects to medication that they might not even need.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news|last1=Edwards|first1=Laurie|title=Women and the Treatment of Pain|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/17/opinion/sunday/women-and-the-treatment-of-pain.html|work=The New York Times|date=16 March 2013}}</ref><!--*<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/how-sexist-stereotypes-mean-doctors-ignore-womens-pain-a7157931.html|title=How sexist stereotypes mean doctors ignore women's pain|date=27 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref>*<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rheumatoidarthritis.net/living/does-sexism-exist-in-healthcare/|title=Does Sexism Exist in Healthcare? - RheumatoidArthritis.net|date=8 March 2016|publisher=}}</ref>--> The report of medical concerns by women are more likely to be discounted, misdiagnosed, ignored and assumed to be [[psychosomatic]].<ref name = huff2017/><ref name = marieclaire>{{cite web|url=http://www.marieclaire.com/health-fitness/a26741/doctors-treat-women-like-men/|title=Women Are Dying Because Doctors Treat Us Like Men|date=25 April 2017|publisher=Marie Claire|last=Adler|first=Kayla Wesley | name-list-format = vanc }}</ref><ref name = nyt/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Chemaly|first1=Soraya|title=How Sexism Affects Women’s Health Every Day - Role Reboot|url=http://www.rolereboot.org/culture-and-politics/details/2015-06-how-sexism-affects-womens-health-every-day/|publisher=Role Reboot|date=23 June 2015}}</ref><!--<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F4olDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA259#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Pelvic Floor Dysfunction and Pelvic Surgery in the Elderly: An Integrated Approach|last=Gordon|first=David A.|last2=Katlic|first2=Mark R. | name-list-format = vanc |date=2017-05-27|publisher=Springer|isbn=9781493965540|language=en}}</ref>--> One observer has stated that, "different forms of female suffering are minimized, mocked, coaxed into silence."<ref name=Atlantic/> There are those that disagree with this characterization.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Boynes-Shuck|first1=Ashley|title=Is There a Gender Bias Against Female Pain Patients?|url=http://www.healthline.com/health-news/gender-bias-against-female-pain-patients|work=Healthline|date=January 31, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name="verilymag.com">{{cite news|last1=Molly Caldwell|first1=Crosby|title=Your Gender Determines the Quality of Your Healthcare (But There's Hope For the Future)|url=https://verilymag.com/2014/05/thats-hysterical-sexism-in-medicine|work=Verily Magazine|date=May 2, 2014 }}</ref>
Clinicians are not as likely to assess women for substance abuse as often as they assess men. They also tend to miss signs of substance addiction in women. Women are not as likely as men to be assessed for alcohol abuse. Out of those women who are found to have an alcohol problem, they were found to be less likely to be referred for treatment. Those women in the childbearing years are prescribed more prescription medications than men. It is generally more common for women to be prescribed [[antipsychotic]]<nowiki/>s and opioids.<ref name="Terplan2017">{{cite journal|vauthors=Terplan M|date=August 2017|title=Women and the opioid crisis: historical context and public health solutions|journal=Fertility and Sterility|volume=108|issue=2|pages=195–199|doi=10.1016/j.fertnstert.2017.06.007|pmid=28697909}}</ref> 
Women report feeling like they were 'silly' by male physicians but female physicians were more sensitive and preferred.<ref name =huff2017/> In a study of multiple men, women, and married couples, it was observed that men’s complaints about physical health were evaluated more in depth than women’s.<ref name=":0">Armitage, K. J., L. J. Schneiderman, and R. A. Bass. “Response of Physicians to Medical Complaints in Men and Women.” ''JAMA'' 241, no. 20 (May 18, 1979): 2186–87.</ref>
[[Sex-selective abortion]] is the medical procedure or treatment that terminates a pregnancy when the baby is an undesired gender. The abortion of female fetuses is most common in areas where the culture values male children over females.<ref>{{Cite journal|last= Goodkind | first = Daniel | name-list-format = vanc |date=1999-01-01|title=Should prenatal sex selection be restricted? Ethical questions and their implications for research and policy |journal=Population Studies|volume=53|issue=1|pages=49–61|doi=10.1080/00324720308069 }}</ref> <ref name="Gettis">A. Gettis, J. Getis, and J. D. Fellmann (2004). Introduction to Geography, Ninth Edition. New York: McGraw-Hill. pp. 200. {{ISBN|0-07-252183-X}}</ref><ref>Canadian Medical Association Journal (2011, March 14). The impact of sex selection and abortion in China, India and South Korea. ScienceDaily. Retrieved March 26, 2012, from https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/03/110314132244.ht{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Sex selective abortion has been heavily utilized in numerous Asian countries. A British medical journal stated: "Compared with the normal ratio of about 95 girls being born per 100 boys (which is what we observe in Europe and North America), Singapore and Taiwan have 92, South Korea 88, and China a mere 86 girls born per 100 boys."<ref>Sen, Amartya. “Missing Women—revisited: Reduction in Female Mortality Has Been Counterbalanced by Sex Selective Abortions.” ''BMJ : British Medical Journal'' 327, no. 7427 (December 6, 2003): 1297. <nowiki>https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.327.7427.1297</nowiki>.</ref>
==Clinical trials and research== Most clinical trials published before 1988 included no women and so many older medications on the market were never evaluated for their effects and side effects on women.<ref name=Schiebinger2003/><ref name=Mazure>{{cite journal | vauthors = Mazure CM, Jones DP | title = Twenty years and still counting: including women as participants and studying sex and gender in biomedical research | journal = BMC Women's Health | volume = 15 | pages = 94 | date = October 2015 | pmid = 26503700 | pmc = 4624369 | doi = 10.1186/s12905-015-0251-9 }}</ref> The physiology of male sex differentiation is described as "well studied, whereas the pathways that regulate female sexual differentiation remain incompletely defined".<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Biason-Lauber A, De Filippo G, Konrad D, Scarano G, Nazzaro A, Schoenle EJ | title = WNT4 deficiency--a clinical phenotype distinct from the classic Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome: a case report | journal = Human Reproduction | volume = 22 | issue = 1 | pages = 224–9 | date = January 2007 | pmid = 16959810 | doi = 10.1093/humrep/del360 | url = https://academic.oup.com/humrep/article/22/1/224/2939474 }}</ref>
In the 1950s and 1960s "women's health' was mostly considered only as [[reproductive health]], and women who were capable of bearing children were excluded from clinical trials to avoid any risk to a potential fetus.<ref name=NAP1994/> Additionally, the [[thalidomide]] tragedy led the FDA to issue regulations in 1977 recommending that women should be excluded from participating in Phase I and Phase II studies in the US.<ref name=Liu2016/> The approach to women shifted from [[paternalism|paternalistic]] protection to access in the early 1980s as AIDS activists like [[ACT UP]] and women's groups challenged ways that drugs were [[drug development|developed]]. The NIH responded with policy changes in 1986, but a Government Accountability Office report in 1990 found that women were still being excluded from clinical research. That report, the appointment of [[Bernadine Healy]] as the first woman to lead the NIH, and the realization that important clinical trials had excluded women led to the creation of the [[Women's Health Initiative]] at the NIH and to the federal legislation, the 1993 National Institutes of Health Revitalization Act, which mandated that women and minorities be included in NIH-funded research.<ref name=NAP1994>{{cite book|last1=Institute of Medicine|editor1-last=Mastroianni|editor1-first=Anna C.|editor2-last=Faden|editor2-first=Ruth|editor3-last=Federman|editor3-first=Daniel | name-list-format = vanc |title=Women and Health Research: Ethical and Legal Issues of Including Women in Clinical Studies, Volume 1|date=1994|publisher=The National Academy Press|isbn=0-309-04992-X|pages=2–3|url=https://www.nap.edu/read/2304/chapter/2|language=en|chapter=Executive Summary}}</ref><ref name=GAO>{{cite book|last1=U.S. Government Accountability Office|title=National Institutes of Health: Problems in Implementing Policy on Women in Study Populations|date=1990|url=http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO/T-HRD-90-50}}</ref><ref name=Schiebinger2003/> The initial large studies on the use of low-dose aspirin to prevent heart attacks that were published in the 1970s and 1980s are often cited as examples of clinical trials that included only men, but from which people drew general conclusions that did not hold true for women.<ref name=Schiebinger2003>{{cite journal | vauthors = Schiebinger L | title = Women's health and clinical trials | journal = The Journal of Clinical Investigation | volume = 112 | issue = 7 | pages = 973–7 | date = October 2003 | pmid = 14523031 | pmc = 198535 | doi = 10.1172/JCI19993 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = | title = Regular aspirin intake and acute myocardial infarction | journal = British Medical Journal | volume = 1 | issue = 5905 | pages = 440–3 | date = March 1974 | pmid = 4816857 | pmc = 1633212 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Elwood PC, Cochrane AL, Burr ML, Sweetnam PM, Williams G, Welsby E, Hughes SJ, Renton R | title = A randomized controlled trial of acetyl salicylic acid in the secondary prevention of mortality from myocardial infarction | journal = British Medical Journal | volume = 1 | issue = 5905 | pages = 436–40 | date = March 1974 | pmid = 4593555 | pmc = 1633246 }}</ref> In 1993 the FDA reversed its 1977 guidance, and included in the new guidance a statement that the former restriction was “rigid and paternalistic, leaving virtually no room for the exercise of judgment by responsible research subjects, physician investigators, and investigational review boards (IRBs)”.<ref name=Liu2016/>
The [[National Academy of Medicine]] published a report called "Women and Health Research: Ethical and Legal Issues of Including Women in Clinical Studies" in 1994<ref name=NAP1994/> and another report in 2001 called "Exploring the Biological Contributions to Human Health: Does Sex Matter?” which each urged including women in clinical trials and running analyses on subpopulations by sex.<ref name=Liu2016>{{cite journal | vauthors = Liu KA, Mager NA | title = Women's involvement in clinical trials: historical perspective and future implications | journal = Pharmacy Practice | volume = 14 | issue = 1 | pages = 708 | date = 2016 | pmid = 27011778 | pmc = 4800017 | doi = 10.18549/PharmPract.2016.01.708 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Institute of Medicine|title=Exploring the Biological Contributions to Human Health: Does Sex Matter?|date=2001|publisher=National Academy Press|isbn=9780309072816|url=https://www.nap.edu/catalog/10028/exploring-the-biological-contributions-to-human-health-does-sex-matter|language=en}}</ref>
A 2005 review by the [[International Council for Harmonisation of Technical Requirements for Pharmaceuticals for Human Use]] found that regulation in the US, Europe, and Japan required that clinical trials should reflect the population to whom an intervention will be given, and found that clinical trials that had been submitted to agencies were generally complying with those regulations.<ref>{{cite web|last1=ICH|title=Gender Considerations in the Conduct of Clinical Trials (EMEA/CHMP/3916/2005)|url=http://www.ema.europa.eu/docs/en_GB/document_library/Scientific_guideline/2010/01/WC500059887.pdf|publisher=EMA|date=5 January 2005}}</ref>
A review of NIH-funded studies (not necessarily submitted to regulatory agencies) published between 1995 and 2010 found that they had an "average enrollment of 37% (±6% standard deviation [SD]) women, at an increasing rate over the years. Only 28% of the publications either made some reference to sex/gender-specific results in the text or provided detailed results including sex/gender-specific estimates of effect or tests of interaction."<ref name=Foulkes>{{cite journal | vauthors = Foulkes MA | title = After inclusion, information and inference: reporting on clinical trials results after 15 years of monitoring inclusion of women | journal = Journal of Women's Health | volume = 20 | issue = 6 | pages = 829–36 | date = June 2011 | pmid = 21671773 | doi = 10.1089/jwh.2010.2527 }}</ref>
The FDA published a study of the 30 sets of clinical trial data submitted after 2011, and found that for all of them, information by sex was available in public documents, and that almost all of them included subanalyses by sex.<ref name=Liu2016/>
As of 2015, recruiting women to participate in clinical trials remained a challenge.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pal|first1=Somnath|title=Inclusion of Women in Clinical Trials of New Drugs and Devices|journal=US Pharm|date=2015|volume=40|issue=10|page=21|url=https://www.uspharmacist.com/article/inclusion-of-women-in-clinical-trials-of-new-drugs-and-devices}}</ref>
In 2018 the US FDA released draft guidelines for inclusion of pregnant women in clinical trials.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dotinga |first1=Randy |title=Pregnant women in clinical trials: FDA questions how to include them |url=https://www.mdedge.com/obgynnews/article/162877/obstetrics/pregnant-women-clinical-trials-fda-questions-how-include-them |work=Ob.Gyn. News |date=April 9, 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Pregnant Women: Scientific and Ethical Considerations for Inclusion in Clinical Trials Guidance for Industry |url=https://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/Guidances/UCM603873.pdf |publisher=FDA |date=April 2018}}</ref>
==Female clinicians== [[Elizabeth Blackwell]] became the first woman to graduate from a Western<ref>{{Cite journal|access-date=2018-04-27|title=Ancient_Egyptian_medicine|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_medicine|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|access-date=2018-04-27|title=Merit-Ptah|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merit-Ptah|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> medical school in 1849.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.medscape.com/features/slideshow/women-physicians|title=Medscape Log In|website=www.medscape.com|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref> To raise awareness of the importance of women physicians, Physician Moms Group and Medelita founded February 3rd as National Women Physicians Day in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Women Physicians Day|url=https://nationaldaycalendar.com/national-women-physicians-day-february-3|website=National Day Calendar|publisher=National Day Calendar|accessdate=27 April 2018}}</ref>
Female clinicians have experienced sexual assault.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in-training.org/sexism-medicine-looks-like-10280|title=What Sexism in Medicine Looks Like |publisher = in-Training|website=in-training.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medicalbag.com/lifestyle/discussing-the-ugly-truth-of-modern-sexism-in-medicine/article/6529--59/|title=Q&A: Discussing the Ugly Truth of Modern Sexism in Medicine|date=26 April 2017|publisher=}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> 30% of female clinicians have reported instances in which they were the victim of sexual harassment.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4337372/30-of-female-doctors-have-been-sexually-harassed/|title=30% of Female Doctors Have Been Sexually Harassed|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref> Sexual harassment is common amongst younger clinicians when they come in contact with male clinicians in power who have more seniority over them.<ref name=":2" /> Due to their sense of power over their coworkers and employees, they feel empowered to commit acts of sexual assault.<ref name=":2" /> When victims of their abuse remain silent, they allow such acts to persist in medical workplaces.<ref name=":2" /> In many cases, the women that come forward about being assaulted have a hard time finding jobs afterwards because they are considered “troublemakers” rather than victims.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://in-training.org/sexism-medicine-looks-like-10280|title=What Sexism in Medicine Looks Like » in-Training, the online magazine for medical students|last=in-Training|website=in-training.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref> This often makes it difficult for the victims to find other jobs in the medical field.<ref name=":3" /> Human Relations also tends to protect their company and its employees they consider assets before protecting those who are their victims.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Jagsi|first=Reshma|date=2018-01-18|title=Sexual Harassment in Medicine — #MeToo|url=https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMp1715962|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=378|issue=3|pages=209–211|doi=10.1056/NEJMp1715962|issn=0028-4793|pmid=29236567}}</ref> This discourages women from speaking up for fear that their jobs may be in jeopardy and that their claims will not be believed.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> Future female employees then suffer the consequences of their silence because the cycle of misconduct continues to occur.<ref name=":4" />
In addition to falling victim to sexual assault in the workplace, female surgeons have also been found to fall victim to the wage gap.<ref name=":5" /> Females were reported to have lower salaries than male surgeons.<ref name=":5" /> In a study conducted in 1990, male clinicians were making a mean earnings of $155,400, while female clinicians were making a mean earnings of $109,900; about $45,500 less than their male counterparts.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Baker|first=Laurence C.|date=1996-04-11|title=Differences in Earnings between Male and Female Physicians|url=https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJM199604113341506|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=334|issue=15|pages=960–964|doi=10.1056/NEJM199604113341506|issn=0028-4793|pmid=8596598}}</ref> As of 2016, female physicians have statistically been found to make about $18,677 less than male physicians.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Desai|first=Tejas|last2=Ali|first2=Sadeem|last3=Fang|first3=Xiangming|last4=Thompson|first4=Wanda|last5=Jawa|first5=Pankaj|last6=Vachharajani|first6=Tushar|date=2016-06-27|title=Equal work for unequal pay: the gender reimbursement gap for healthcare providers in the United States|url=http://pmj.bmj.com/content/early/2016/06/27/postgradmedj-2016-134094|journal=Postgraduate Medical Journal|language=en|pages=postgradmedj–2016–134094|doi=10.1136/postgradmedj-2016-134094|issn=0032-5473|pmid=27528703}}</ref> Disparities between male and female surgeons has also been blamed upon not being as qualified as men to commit to leadership roles that earn them higher salaries.<ref name=":6" /> Yet women are just as willing as men to accept positions of leadership when they are equally qualified. In many cases, women clinicians are equal to men at leadership tasks.<ref name="zhuge">{{cite journal | vauthors = Zhuge Y, Kaufman J, Simeone DM, Chen H, Velazquez OC | title = Is there still a glass ceiling for women in academic surgery? | journal = Annals of Surgery | volume = 253 | issue = 4 | pages = 637–43 | date = April 2011 | pmid = 21475000 | doi = 10.1097/SLA.0b013e3182111120 }}</ref> Other clinicians have expressed that they believe women in medicine are less committed to their careers and women are less effective as leaders.<ref name=":1" />
Moreover, female clinicians have also experienced barriers within finding the support to balance both working and having or maintaining a family. It has been reported that females are more likely to return back to work after having a child part-time as opposed to full-time because they lack the support they receive by both their employers and society as a whole. It was found that the percentage of female clinicians working part-time in either a hospital setting or a general physician’s office after having a child is much higher than the percentage of these women working full time after having a child (92.7%, 96.3% 59.2%, 76.5% respectively). <ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Reed|first=V|date=2001|title=Career Obstacles for Women in Medicine: An Overview|url=|journal=MEDICAL EDUCATION –OXFORD|volume=no.2|pages=139|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref>Not only is there a difference within the percentage of females working part time and full time, there is also a relatively large difference within the percentages of female clinicians returning to their job in the hospital or in a general physicians office. Unfortunately, women are less likely to return back full time if having worked in the hospital because those shifts require longer hours and a lot of help that they may not be receiving.
Furthermore, female physician narratives have described instances of sexism.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Koven S|date=May 2017|title=Letter to a Young Female Physician|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=376|issue=20|pages=1907–1909|doi=10.1056/NEJMp1702010|pmid=28514609}}</ref> Female physicians are often mistaken for nurses by patients.<ref name=":3" /> Patients have also been reported to have less trust in their physician if they are female and instead ask for a second opinion from a male physician.<ref name=":3" /> Women physicians, on the other hand, have also been found to partake in sexist actions. Female clinicians often treat women patients differently than they do men.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.acsh.org/news/2018/02/13/do-women-physicians-treat-women-patients-differently-12567|title=Do Women Physicians Treat Women Patients Differently? {{!}} American Council on Science and Health|website=www.acsh.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref> Women physicians were found to admit less female patients to intensive care units because they were proactive in treating them in the emergency room, rendering their admittance to more intense care units unnecessary.<ref name=":7" />
==Male clinicians==
Men often decide to become nurses for self-actualization or survival needs, or simply because their original plans did not work out. However, there are a handful of men who decide to become nurses and start their studies with that goal in mind. Unfortunately, when men enter the field of nursing, they encounter many barriers that limit their choice of specialty. They run the risk of being labeled and stereotyped. These gender biases and role stereotyping occur because of the fact that nursing facilities are often composed mainly of women. Nursing tends to be identified with feminine style of care.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kouta|first=Christina|date=2011|title=Gender Discrimination and Nursing|url=https://ac.els-cdn.com/S8755722310001468/1-s2.0-S8755722310001468-main.pdf?_tid=841c9e65-25d6-47d1-bddf-c29cea94ce0e&acdnat=1523315142_2628a13261b5f42cbfe83c9cfb9c3311|journal=Journal of Professional Nursing|volume=27|pages=59-63|via=}}</ref>
Males only make up 9% of nurses. Stereotyping of men is related to nursing being considered a profession for women.<ref name="kron">{{cite journal|last1=Kronsberg|first1=Suzanne|last2=Bouret|first2=Josephine Rachel|last3=Brett|first3=Anne Liners | name-list-format = vanc |title=Lived experiences of male nurses: Dire consequences for the nursing profession|journal=Journal of Nursing Education and Practice|volume=8|issue=1|year=2017|pages=46|issn=1925-4059|doi=10.5430/jnep.v8n1p46}}</ref> Men tend to face two common stereotypes when it comes to being nurses. The first being the stereotype that male nurses are gay since they are in a “feminine occupation.” The other common stereotype is that men are generally hypersexual and that this will inhibit them from being able to provide intimate care to women in nonsexual ways.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=|title=Heteronormative Labour|url=http://eds.b.ebscohost.com/eds/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=2&sid=32c8867a-e474-43e9-9c84-1f36707061ec%40sessionmgr104|journal=Gender, Work, and Organization|volume=23|pages=|via=}}</ref>
Issues regarding sexism in/against male clinicians are harder to describe except possibly by example. Male nurses report:
* being mistaken for a doctor * being asked to see the 'pretty' nurse * being called 'Doc' even when the patient knew the man was a nurse * being discounted as 'only' a nurse rather than a doctor by other professionals * being asked: "when are you going to become a doctor?" * being told that a female nurse is preferred<ref name = nurse>{{cite web|url=http://minoritynurse.com/male-nurses-confronting-stereotypes-and-discrimination-part-1-the-issues/|title=Male Nurses Confronting Stereotypes and Discrimination: Part 1, The Issues - Minority Nurse|website=minoritynurse.com|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> *being bullied on the job *being teased as a child for wanting to be a nurse<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2017/mar/01/why-so-few-male-nurses|title=Why are there so few male nurses?|first=Rachel|last=Williams | name-list-format = vanc |date=1 March 2017|publisher=|access-date=4 September 2017|via=The Guardian}}</ref>
Other questions are often asked of male nurses such as 'why did you go into nursing'? Or they are asked if they are [[gay]] failed medical school and became a nurse because it was easier. Sometimes a male nurse can be asked if he is nurse so that he can see undressed women.<ref name = nurse/> In some instances male nurses were assumed to be the 'muscle' for other female nurses. Nursing supervisors tended to ask patients if it was alright to assign a male nurse to provide care. Male nurses have reported bias directed toward them during their studies. They experienced anxiety, insomnia, anger, and trepidation in anticipation of being treated poorly.<ref name=kron/>
Another difficulty that male nurses face is that they are passed over for work with female patients, or they are not allowed on birthing or gynecological units. This is concerning due to the fact that male doctors are completely welcome in these situations. In addition, male nurses find that they are pushed toward tasks that are stereotypically consistent with their gender role. Some of these might include heavy lifting, administrative roles, or psychiatric nursing.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Clow|first=Kimberley|date=September 2014|title=Are You Man Enough to be a Nurse?|url=http://eds.b.ebscohost.com/eds/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=16&sid=32c8867a-e474-43e9-9c84-1f36707061ec%40sessionmgr104|journal=Springer|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
==Medical education== Women are underrepresented in leadership positions in academic medicine. Women and men begin their medical careers at similar rates but they do not advance at the same rate.<ref name=":1" /> Studies indicate a systematic bias that has resulted in relatively fewer appointments to academic chairs.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Grant-Kels JM | title = Sexism in medicine, circa 2016-2017 | journal = International Journal of Women's Dermatology | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 68–69 | date = March 2017 | pmid = 28492058 | doi = 10.1016/j.ijwd.2017.01.007 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352647517300072 }}</ref><ref name="huff2017" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.healthline.com/health-news/sexism-is-alive-in-healthcare|title=Sexism Is Alive, Well in the Healthcare Industry|last1=Haskins|first1=Julia|date=March 25, 2016|work=Healthline|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":02">{{cite journal|last1=Armato|first1=Michael|date=July 2013|title=Wolves in Sheep's Clothing: Men's Enlightened Sexism & Hegemonic Masculinity in Academia|journal=Women's Studies|volume=42|issue=5|pages=578–598|doi=10.1080/00497878.2013.794055}}</ref><ref name=":12">{{cite journal|last1=Savigny|first1=Heather|date=24 October 2014|title=Women, know your limits: cultural sexism in academia|journal=Gender and Education|volume=26|issue=7|pages=794–809|doi=10.1080/09540253.2014.970977}}</ref> Thirty-two percent of associate professors at medical schools are women, 32% of associate professors are women, 20% of full professors are women, 14% of department chairs are women, and 11% of deans of medical schools are women.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | vauthors = Carnes M, Bartels CM, Kaatz A, Kolehmainen C | title = Why is John More Likely to Become Department Chair Than Jennifer? | journal = Transactions of the American Clinical and Climatological Association | volume = 126 | pages = 197–214 | date = 2015 | pmid = 26330674 | pmc = 4530686 }}</ref>
A factor that impedes women’s opportunities for advancement in academic medicine is a “stereotype-based cognitive bias.” There are two forms of this. The first type is related to clear personal beliefs about women, such as believing that women are less committed to their careers than men and believing that women are worse leaders than men. The second type is implicit bias, which is harder to see because the biases are harder to see, but they still influence one’s judgment and actions towards women. Although implicit gender bias still plays a role, explicit bias in academic medicine has significantly decreased during the past half century in the United States as a result of Title IX getting passed. Implicit bias has had little to no improvement. Cultural stereotypes characterize women as “communal,” such as kind, dependent, and nurturing, but characterize women as lacking “agentric” traits, such as logical, independent, and strong, which are typically used as a male stereotype. These stereotypes make it difficult for women to achieve in the workforce, specifically in medicine, science, and in leadership. While men are associated with “agentic” traits and women are not, this can lead to women feeling that their work is less valued and they typically receive fewer nominations for opportunities that can advance their career. It has also been found that gender stereotypes play a role in socializing students towards their specialties. For example, women are more likely to go into communal specialties, including family medicine, pediatrics, and internal medicine, while men are more likely to go into surgery, research, and be the chair of a position. If women to go into specialties dominated by males, they typically have lower statuses. Residency is the first time the medical students, or new physicians, get to be in a leadership role. Men who are too communal can be accused of being “wimpy” or “soft” whereas women who are too agentic can be accused of being “bossy” or “domineering.”<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Carnes M, Bartels CM, Kaatz A, Kolehmainen C | title = Why is John More Likely to Become Department Chair Than Jennifer? | journal = Transactions of the American Clinical and Climatological Association | volume = 126 | pages = 197–214 | date = 2015 | pmid = 26330674 | pmc = 4530686 }}</ref>
These stereotypes are due to the lack of gender awareness and role models. Female medical students have reported sexual harassment and discrimination. This is of concern because these obstacles affect "the professional identity formation and specialty choice." Personality differences exist between male and female surgical students. Fewer women choose to specialize in surgery. The lack of female role models may discourage some from choosing a surgical career.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Burgos CM, Josephson A | title = Gender differences in the learning and teaching of surgery: a literature review | journal = International Journal of Medical Education | volume = 5 | pages = 110–24 | date = June 2014 | pmid = 25341220 | doi = 10.5116/ijme.5380.ca6b | url = https://www.ijme.net/archive/5/gender-differences-in-learning-and-teaching-of-surgery/?ref=linkout }}</ref>
A study by the National Medical Foundation found that 60% of women have reported that gender has had an effect on their educational experience whereas only 25% of males have reported that gender has had an effect on their educational experience. Women said they felt as though they had to be twice as good to be treated equal to men. Additionally, 30.7% of women reported overcoming fear and failure whereas only 19.4% of males reported overcoming fear and failure in education.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bright CM, Duefield CA, Stone VE | title = Perceived barriers and biases in the medical education experience by gender and race | journal = Journal of the National Medical Association | volume = 90 | issue = 11 | pages = 681–8 | date = November 1998 | pmid = 9828583 | pmc = 2608378 }}</ref>
One response to bias against women academics has been to conduct training for faculty and students to recognize bias and change their habits.<ref name=":1" />
==Wage gap== Communal specialties, which women are more likely to go into, often have a lower pay than the specialties in which men typically go into. Women have been found to have a larger representation than men in lower-paying specialties, such as pediatrics and men lave a larger representation in higher-paying specialties, such as cardiology and surgery. In New York State between 1999 and 2008, the average starting salary for men was $187,385 whereas the mean starting salary for women was $158,727.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lo Sasso AT, Richards MR, Chou CF, Gerber SE | title = The $16,819 pay gap for newly trained physicians: the unexplained trend of men earning more than women | journal = Health Affairs | volume = 30 | issue = 2 | pages = 193–201 | date = February 2011 | pmid = 21289339 | doi = 10.1377/hlthaff.2010.0597 }}</ref> In 2001, it was found that male physicians earned roughly around 41% more than their female colleagues.<ref name=":8" /> As of 2017, an updated version then found that the percentage had dropped to roughly around 27.7%<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://money.cnn.com/2018/03/14/news/economy/gender-pay-gap-doctors/index.html|title=The gender pay gap for women doctors is big -- and getting worse|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. That is roughly around a 100,000 dollar difference in salary per year. However, interestingly enough, women who work in radiology are the only women who make more than their male colleagues and the difference is only about 2,000 dollars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wimlf.org/news/post/37|title=THE WAGE GAP IN MEDICINE: WHAT WE KNOW|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> A study published in 2005 found that women physicians in the US had an annual earning gap of 11% if they were married, 14% if they had one child, and 22% if they had more than one child. Women typically had household obligations that affected their ability to work as much as men and therefore led to a trade-off of higher earnings for family-friendly jobs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sasser|first=Alicia C. | name-list-format = vanc |date=2005|title=Gender Differences in Physician Pay: Tradeoffs between Career and Family|jstor=4129534|journal=The Journal of Human Resources|volume=40|issue=2|pages=477–504}}</ref>
==History== During the Salem Witch Trials in the late 1600s, women were disproportionately accused of witchcraft due to induced seizures induced by mold. Despite ergotism affecting both male and female populations, young females were more likely to be tried and killed for witchcraft.<ref>Woolf, Alan. 2000. “Witchcraft or Mycotoxin? The Salem Witch Trials.” ''Journal of Toxicology:''
''Clinical Toxicology'' 38 (4): 457–60. <nowiki>https://doi.org/10.1081/CLT-100100958</nowiki>.</ref>
During the late 1800s, physicians (predominately male) described physical ailments of women as '[[hysteria]]'. In 1948 some women volunteered to take part in an [[experiment]] designed to quantify pain in [[childbirth|laboring women]]. During their labor, their hands were burned.<ref name="verilymag.com" />
In a 1979 observational study, 104 women and men gave responses to their health in 5 areas: “back pain, headaches, dizziness, chest pain, and fatigue. When receiving these complaints, it was seen that doctors gave extensive checkups to men more often than women with similar complaints, supporting that female patients tend to be taken less seriously than their male counterparts with regard to receiving medical illnesses. <ref name=":0" />
In 1990, the [[National Institutes of Health]] recognized the disparities in research of disease in men and when. At this time the Office of Research on Women’s Health was created. A large part of its purpose is to raise awareness of sex affects disease and treatments.<ref name = "verilymag.com"/><ref name = huff2017/> In 1991 and 1992 recognition that a 'glass ceiling' existed which prevented from female clinicians from being promoted.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Madsen MK, Blide LA | title = Professional advancement of women in health care management: a conceptual model | journal = Topics in Health Information Management | volume = 13 | issue = 2 | pages = 45–55 | date = November 1992 | pmid = 10122424 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wiggins C | title = Female healthcare managers and the glass ceiling. The obstacles and opportunities for women in management | journal = Hospital Topics | volume = 69 | issue = 1 | pages = 8–14 | date = 3 September 1991 | pmid = 10109490 | doi = 10.1080/00185868.1991.9948448 }}</ref> In 1994 the FDA created an Office of Women’s Health by congressional mandate.<ref name="Liu2016" />
==Gender Roles==
According to a study done in 2003, it can be seen that the numbers of women in medicine have increased significantly. This trend continues into today. In the United States, there has actually been a “progressive decrease in male applicants to medicine and a substantial rise in female applicants.” Gender difference have been found in the motivations for applying to medical school. Studies suggest that “male applicants are more motivated by financial, prestige, scientific and technical issues, whereas female applicants stress more ‘person orientated’ humanistic and altruistic reasons.” Gender differences have also been found in “attitudes toward health promotion.” In addition, male and female clinicians are likely to use different styles of communication. Male doctors were found to be more likely to “speak in an authoritative manner, give direct commands to patients, interrupt more, are perceived as more imposing and presumptuous, spend less time with patients, make fewer positive statements and smile and nod less.” Some studies have found that female doctors “provide more intensive therapeutic milieu that could lead to more open exchange and comprehensive diagnosis and treatment.” In addition, females have been found to take more precautionary measures and give more tests than men are<ref>Kilminster, Sue, et al. “Women in Medicine. Is There a Problem? A Literature Review of the Changing Gender Composition, Structures and Occupational Cultures in Medicine.” Medical Education, vol. 41, no. 1, 2007, pp. 39-49., doi:10.1111/j.1365-2929.2006.02645.x. </ref>.
There is also a connection between gender roles in the medical field and family pressures. A study was done to determine how doctors combine their working lives with having a normal family life. This study analyzes three different strategies used by men and women in order to cope with managing a normal family life and a work-heavy career. The three different types of strategies that men and women use are “career dominant, segregated, and accommodated.” When it comes to the career dominant strategy, about 15% of women and 3% of men adopt this strategy. This strategy “implies a continuous, full time career and a reduced family life- living single or divorced and childless as a consequence of the career.” The segregated strategy is composed of 55% of women and 85% of men, and it “implies a continuous, full time career with family roles organized so as to enable more time to be devoted to the career.” And lastly, the accommodating strategy is adopted by 30% of women and 12% of men. This strategy “implies that work involvement has been reduced in some way to allow more time for family roles.” As can be seen by these statistics, men are more likely than women to devote more time to their job as opposed to their family.<ref>Theorell, T. “Changing Society: Changing Role of Doctors.” Bmj, vol. 320, no. 7247, 2000, pp. 1417-1418., doi: 10.1136/bmj.320.7247.1417. </ref>

{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | name = The Conservative Case for Trump | author = [[Phyllis Schlafly]] | language = English | country = United States | published = 2016 | publisher = | isbn = 978-1-62157-628-0 | italic title = | image = The Conservative Case for Trump.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | orig_lang_code = en | subject = [[Donald Trump]] | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]), [[Amazon Kindle|Kindle]] [[E-book]] | pages = }} {{Donald Trump series}} '''''The Conservative Case for Trump''''' is a 2016 book by [[Phyllis Schlafly]], a [[movement conservative]] best known for helping to defeat the [[Equal Rights Amendment]] in the 1970s.{{cite web | last1=Thorner | first1=Nancy | title=Thorner: 'The Conservative Case for Trump' Takes on Special Meaning with Schlafly's Death | url=http://illinoisreview.typepad.com/illinoisreview/2016/09/thorner-the-conservative-case-for-trump-takes-on-special-meaning-with-schlaflys-death.html | date=September 7, 2016 | publisher=''Illinois Review'' | accessdate=September 25, 2016}} It was her final book, being published posthumously.{{cite web|url=https://www.regnery.com/books/the-conservative-case-for-trump/|website=Regency Publishing|accessdate=13 March 2018}} The book was published in September 2016, following the nomination of [[Donald Trump]] for [[President of the United States]], and explains in detail Schlafly's rationale for viewing Trump a serious conservative and a better candidate than [[Hillary Clinton]]. The book, co-written by [[Ed Martin (Missouri politician)|Ed Martin]] and [[Brett M. Decker]],{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/09/07/politics/phyllis-schlafly-donald-trump-book/index.html|title=When Phyllis Schlafly made the case for Donald Trump|first=Eugene|last=Scott|work=cnn.com|date=September 7, 2016|accessdate=25 September 2016}} describes Trump's anti-establishment stances on the following issues: * [[bureaucracy|bureaucratic regulations]] * [[education]] * [[family values]] * [[illegal immigration]] * [[judicial activism]] * [[political correctness]] * [[social security]] * the [[U.S. military]] * [[trade]] One argument the book makes is that Republicans who do not support Trump would wind up helping to elect Hillary Clinton instead of him."This book by Phyllis Schlafly, Ed Martin, and Brett Decker shows why Republicans not supporting Trump are helping elect Hillary Clinton." —[[Laura Ingraham]] It also argues that Republicans and independents ought to "unify behind his candidacy".
"In The Conservative Case for Trump, Phyllis Schlafly, Ed Martin, and Brett M. Decker show how President Trump can get our country back on the right track, and why Republicans and independents need to unify behind his candidacy."—Newt Gingrich (See [[William F. Buckley Jr.#Buckley Rule|Buckley Rule]].) The book's publication followed Schlafly's tussle with the board of the [[Eagle Forum]] after she unilaterally endorsed Trump's presidency. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Trump media}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Conservative Case For Trump}} [[Category:2016 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Books about the United States presidential election, 2016]] [[Category:Books about Donald Trump]] [[Category:Books published posthumously]]

page.title: The Politics of Social Change in the Middle East and North Africa

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
'''The Politics of Social Change in the Middle East and North Africa''' is a 1963 book by [[Manfred Halpern]]. For years it was "the only academic treatment of [[Islamism]]," and served as "the basic text" on the politics of the Arab world for a generation of students.<ref name=KramerWar>{{cite book|last1=Kramer|first1=Martin|title=The War on Error|date=2016|publisher=Trnasaction Publishers|page=72|accessdate=24 December 2016}}</ref>
''Politics of Social change'' was written at the behest of the [[RAND Corporation]] and published by [[Princeton University Press]].<ref name=MacDonaldHistory>{{cite book|last1=MacDonald|first1=David Bruce|title=Thinking History, Fighting Evil|date=2009|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=0739125036|page=99}}</ref> It was widely reviewed and went through 6 printings.<ref name=KramerWar/>
==Neo-Islamic Totalitarianism==
Halpern describes the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and similar [[Islamist]] movements as a new kind of "Neo-Islamic Totalitarianism" best understood as a uniquely Islamic form of [[fascism]]. He argued that it is distinctive in drawing on a deeply Islamic apocalyptic tradition whereby at times of crises "an apocalyptic vision of spiritual and political redemption" comes to the fore. That modernity and urbanization deprived enormous numbers of people of livelihoods, and attracting many to faith and to an ideological rejection of material goods, while the literacy produced by urban life and modernity enable them to access religious texts. And that Islamic fascism drew these seekers to charismatic leaders who offered "an intoxicating sense of nihilism" in an atmosphere in which leaders made [[martyrdom]] into a spiritual goal and followers were "sent to death as robots" with the "illusion of dying as martyrs". <ref name=MacDonaldHistory/>
He described the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] as aiming to unify all Muslims under a new caliphate.<ref name=MacDonaldHistory/>
==Criticism==
Frédéric Volpi argues that Halpern's work represents a mix of mid-[[Cold War]] and [[orientalism]]. <ref name=Volpe>{{cite journal |title = Political Islam in the Mediterranean: the view from democratization studies |last = Volpi |first = Frédéric |journal = [[Routledge|Democratization]] |volume = 16 |issue = 1 |year = 2009 |pages = 22f |url = https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/media/school-of-international-relations/bsmes/documents/political-islam-in-the-mediterranean.pdf |ref = harv |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161225215312/https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/media/school-of-international-relations/bsmes/documents/political-islam-in-the-mediterranean.pdf |archivedate = 2016-12-25 |df = }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''The Triangle Network '''(formally known as the''' '''Triangle Arts Trust) is an international arts organization that brings together artists from different countries to explore new ideas and expand the boundaries of their practice. Triangle was initiated through a series of artists' workshops providing an uninterrupted period of two weeks where 20–25 artists from diverse [[culture|cultural]] backgrounds engage with each other, to explore new ideas and expand the boundaries of their practice. Now the Triangle Network coalesces grassroots arts organisations around the world (many of which were initiated as workshops while others grew independently), in order that artists' mobility, international cultural exchange and capacity building objectives can be shared.
The Triangle Network is registered as a charitable organization in the [[UK]].<ref>http://www.charitycommission.gov.uk/registeredcharities/ScannedAccounts/Ends11%5C0000326411_AC_20040331_E_C.pdf</ref>
==History== The Triangle Network was established in 1982 by [[Robert Loder]] and [[Anthony Caro]], and is organised as a network of [[artist]]s, [[visual art]] organisations, and artists-led workshops. It currently is active in over 30 countries. Each centre within the Network is independent and set up to respond to local needs. The object of the workshops is "to counterbalance the tendency of the Western art world to put the emphasis on the object and its marketing rather than on the creative process itself". <ref name=remix>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rQbiP0M5tCUC&pg=PA252&lpg=PA252&dq=Triangle+Arts+Trust&source=bl&ots=Qob4VJMGjm&sig=WZ7XXyUMOlxZBAJKE3yF6pkRLVU&hl=en&ei=ZDAAS-vDApS1lAecncmWCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CBgQ6AEwBThG#v=onepage&q=Triangle%20Arts%20Trust&f=false|title=Africa Remix|work=google.com|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
David Elliott was appointed to Chair the Board, succeeding Robert Loder who retired in 2009. Loder remained a Trustee of the organization until 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artdaily.org/index.asp?int_sec=11&int_new=32071|title=Triangle Arts Trust Announced the Appointment of David Elliott as the Chair of the Board of Triangle Arts Trust|author=Ignacio Villarreal|work=artdaily.org|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>

===[[Middle East]]=== *Al Mahatta, [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.wafa.ps/page.aspx?id=GnpTKxa12554573823aGnpTKx|title=Gallery Al-Mahatta: Manifestation of Complicity with Self|website=وكالة الأنباء والمعلومات الفلسطينية - وفا|access-date=2018-08-19}}</ref> *Batroun Projects, [[Lebanon]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.98weeks.net/p/98events.html|title=WORKSHOPS AND EVENTS|website=www.98weeks.net|access-date=2018-08-19}}</ref> *Wasla Workshop, [[Egypt]]<ref name="remix" /> *Open Studio Project [[Cairo, Egypt]]<ref name="openstudiocairo">{{cite web|url=http://www.openstudiocairo.com/files/opensound/OSP%20overview.pdf |date=27 April 2006 |title=Open Studio Project 2006 |author=Townhouse Gallery |accessdate=20 August 2015 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060824092834/http://www.openstudiocairo.com/files/opensound/OSP%20overview.pdf |archivedate=August 24, 2006 }}</ref> *[[Rybon Art Center]], [[Tehran]], [[Iran]]
===[[Africa]]=== *32° East, [[Uganda]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.arterialnetwork.org/opportunity/32deg|title=Programme Manager, 32° East {{!}} Ugandan Arts Trust|access-date=2018-08-19|language=en}}</ref> *ABRO International Workshop, [[Addis Ababa, Ethiopia]] <ref>http://ethiopia.africancolours.net/content/16381</ref> *Aftershave workshop, [[Nigeria]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aftershaveworkshop.org/|title=芸術的なワークショップ情報局|work=aftershaveworkshop.org|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> *Bag Factory, [[Johannesburg, South Africa|Johannesburg]]<ref name=remix /> *Batapata workshop, [[Zimbabwe]]<ref name=remix /> *Greatmore Studios, [[Cape Town, South Africa|Cape Town]]<ref name=remix /> *Kuona Trust & Wasanii workshop, [[Kenya]]<ref>http://www.kuonatrust.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=L1T%2Fa7vb1Zo%3D&tabid=100&mid=426</ref> *Mbile/Insaka workshops, [[Zambia]] *Ngoma workshop, [[Uganda]]<ref name=remix /> *Njelele, [[Zimbabwe]] *Pachipamwe workshop, [[Zimbabwe]]<ref name="remix" /> *Partage, [[Mauritius]] *Rafiki workshop, [[Tanzania]]<ref name=remix /> *Rockston Studios, [[Zambia]]<ref name=remix /> *Tenq workshop, [[Senegal]]<ref name=remix /> *Thapong workshop, [[Botswana]]<ref name=remix /> *Thupelo workshop, Cape Town and [[Johannesburg, South Africa|Johannesburg]] <ref name=remix /> *[[Tulipamwe]] workshop, [[Namibia]]<ref name=remix /> *Ujamaa workshop, [[Mozambique]]

Nafas Art Magazine|publisher=universes-in-universe.org|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> *Village workshop, [[Rajasthan, India|Rajasthan]]

===[[South America]]=== *Capacete, [[Brazil]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.trianglenetwork.org/triangle-network/partners/|title=Triangle Network Partners {{!}} Triangle Network|website=www.trianglenetwork.org|access-date=2018-08-19}}</ref> *El Basilisco, [[Argentina]] *Festival de Performance, [[Cali, Colombia]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://realtimearts.net/article/issue74/8183|title=RealTime Arts - Magazine - issue 74 - Festival in Cali: artists-run, people driven|work=realtimearts.net|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> *Helena Producciones, [[Colombia]] *Kiosko/Simple, [[Bolivia]] *Km0 (kilometro zero), [[Bolivia]] *La Llama, [[Venezuela]] *Lugar a Dudas, [[Colombia]] *PIVÔ, [[Brazil]] *URRA, [[Argentina]]
